title: Arthur Francis Basset Hull
text:
Arthur Francis Basset Hull (1862–1945) was an Australian <a href="philatelist">philatelist</a> who signed the <a href="Roll%20of%20Distinguished%20Philatelists">Roll of Distinguished Philatelists</a> in 1921. Hull was born on 10 October 1862 in <a href="Hobart">Hobart</a> At age 15 , Hull suffered <a href="polio">polio</a> so had to wearing a surgical boot and a <a href="walking%20stick">walking stick</a> for the rest of his life.
Tasmania.
In 1883-89 Hull worked as <a href="clerk">clerk</a> in the <a href="Supreme%20court">Supreme Court</a>. In 1880s, Hull worked as <a href="secretary">secretary</a> and <a href="treasurer">treasurer</a> for the Orpheus Club. In 1888 he published a series of short stories called "A Strange Experience".
Sydney.
On 12 October 1892 Hull moved to <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> to work as clerk for the <a href="General%20Post%20Office%2C%20Sydney">General Post Officer</a>. On 1 July 1900, Hull received a transfer to the <a href="Department%20of%20Public%20Works">Department of Public Works</a> as a secretary to labour commissioners. In January 1903 Hull worked in Department of Mines until his retirement in 1921.
Personal life.
On 29 April 1891 at Congregational Church , <a href="Newtown%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Newtown</a> Hull married Laura Blanche Nisbet. The couple had a son and Nisbet died in 1893. In March 1899 Hull was <a href="Lawsuit">sued</a> by Bertha Cligny de Boissac for breach of marriage promise. Hull was unable to pay Boissac £500 in damages he was forced to declare <a href="bankruptcy">bankruptcy</a>. At <a href="Annadale%2C%20South%20Australia">Annadale</a> on 15 January 1902 , Hull married Caroline Ann Lloyd. In 1912 Hull divorced his second wife Caroline. On 3 December 1926 in <a href="Manly%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Manly</a> he married Diana Farley. Hull died on 22 September 1945 and was cremated with Anglican rites.
Hull worked as secretary and president to <a href="Royal%20Zoological%20Society%20of%20New%20South%20Wales">Royal Zoological Society of New South Wales</a> from 1917-1919 , 1928–29 and 1938-39. Hull was a member of Taronga Zoological Park Trust from 1926. Hull served as president <a href="Royal%20Australasian%20Ornithologists%20Union">Royal Australasian Ornithologists' Union</a> in 1919-1920 and the <a href="Linnean%20Society%20of%20New%20South%20Wales">Linnean Society</a> in 1923-1924 also publishing in their journal publications. In 1917-1945, Hull worked with <a href="Australian%20Museum">Australia Museum</a> as <a href="Honorary%20title%20%28academic%29">honorary</a> <a href="Ornithology">ornithologist .</a>
Since Childhood , Hull collected stamps and was an <a href="Honorary%20title%20%28academic%29">honorary fellow</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Philatelic%20Society%20London">Royal Philatelic Society London</a>, from 1887. Hull published many articles including "Stamps of Tasmania" , "The Postage Stamps of New South Wales" and "The Postage Stamps of Queensland".
